Therefore if / с = 2 is admissible,  is a Reynolds operator when T is,  and hence has
the form fk { z ) for some к and ca,  which is impossible. 
For the case Æ = 3,  a more laborious calculation leads to
{ E — T ){{ E + П [ Т ^ а-ТЩ—Т ^{ Т ^ а-Ъ + а ^ ТЧ )] = О ( all a,  ft € Ф ( Г )),
so that is a Reynolds operator if T is one and if M PtSp ( T ). Suppose an S exists in Theorem 3 for which 1 i PtSp ( S ) ; then it follows from the proof of the theorem
that z ® has the form /^( z ) for some к and ca,  which again is impossible. 
I am unable,  so far,  to settle the admissibility of general values of k. 
Acknowledgment,  I must thank Mr P.  Daniell for drawing the diagrams. 
References
[ 1 ] M,  Billik and Ö. - C.  Rota,  On Reynolds operators in finite-dimensional algebras,  J.  of Math,  and Mechanics 9 ( 1960 ), 927—932.
